<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Good morning. </strong>This is your friendly neighborhood business newsletter checking in to make sure you're registered to vote, and if not, point you in the right direction.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Thing is, those directions aren't that complicated. We've got a website, <a href="https://vote.morningbrew.com/" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Brew Votes</a>, that allows you to check your registration status and/or register to vote. To sweeten the deal, we'll send you an exclusive Brew Votes sticker sheet when you brag to your friends about registering on social media. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The registration deadline for many states is coming up <em>really </em>fast, so don't procrastinate any longer and <a href="https://vote.morningbrew.com/" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">register to vote</a>. </p>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
TAXES
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/09/27/nyt-releases-explosive-report-president-trumps-tax-history?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
The New York Times Dumps Trump’s Taxes
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="NEW YORK, NY - SEPTEMBER 22, 2017:  Black limousines pass in front of Tr..." style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yNTM1L25ld195b3JrX2NpdHlfY2FuZGlkX3NjZW4uanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Robert Alexander/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Last night, the New York Times released a <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/09/27/us/donald-trump-taxes.html?referringSource=articleShare&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">detailed rundown</a> of President Trump’s financial dealings based on tax return data spanning more than two decades. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Go ahead and slap the “bombshell” label on this investigation, because the president's tax returns are some of the most sought-after documents in the world. Trump, who ran a sprawling business operation before running for president, broke precedent by becoming the first president since the 1970s to keep his tax returns under wraps. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Key takeaways</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">For a billionaire, Trump paid very little income tax. </strong>In 10 of 15 years leading up to his 2016 election, Trump paid $0 of federal income tax “largely because he reported losing much more money than he made," the NYT writes. In 2016 and 2017, he paid $750 each year. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">He made a lot of money from saying “You’re fired.” </strong>Trump’s TV show <em>The Apprentice </em>brought in <a href="https://www.axios.com/nyt-trump-paid-750-in-federal-income-taxes-in-2016-and-2017-b15150cd-1a05-4e6e-8f0d-7dfd2c2fa1ac.html?utm_source=twitter&utm_medium=social&utm_campaign=organic&utm_content=1100&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">$427.4 million</a> including licensing and endorsement deals associated with his personal brand. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The NYT also found that he took tax deductions on $70,000 he spent on hairstyling for his television appearances. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Golf is a tough business for Trump.</strong> The report found that many of the president’s signature properties, including his various golf courses and hotels, have been losing millions of dollars every year, resulting in lower taxes. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">A bill looms</strong>. More than $300 million in loans that Trump is personally responsible for will come due in the next four years, per the NYT. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">What Trump is saying</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Trump’s camp is beating the “fake news” drum once again. “Most, if not all, of the facts appear to be inaccurate,” a Trump Organization lawyer told the NYT, going on to say in a statement that President Trump has paid “millions in personal taxes since announcing his candidacy in 2015.”</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>In a press conference last night, Trump echoed his lawyer, saying that an IRS audit of his taxes is currently underway and will paint a more accurate picture. “It’ll all be revealed,” </span><span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/sep/27/new-york-times-publishes-donald-trumps-tax-returns-election?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">he said</a></span><span>. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>you can bet this report will be brought up in the <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2020/09/27/politics/biden-trump-no-handshake-first-presidential-debate/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">first debate</a> between President Trump and Joe Biden tomorrow night. The NYT also promised to release additional investigations related to these tax documents in the coming weeks.</p>

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
JUSTICE
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/09/27/president-trump-nominates-judge-amy-coney-barrett-supreme-court?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Barrett's the Pick
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Judge Amy Coney Barret " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yNTMyL2p1ZGdlX2FteV9jb25leV9iYXJyZXQuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Chen Mengtong/China News Service via Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">On Saturday, President Trump <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2020/09/27/politics/amy-coney-barrett-supreme-court-trump-election-2020/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">nominated</a> Judge Amy Coney Barrett, a conservative favorite, to occupy the Supreme Court seat vacated when Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg died over a week ago. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">A longtime Notre Dame law professor and a clerk to the late Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia in the 1990s, Barrett is considered a “<a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/what-trump-pick-amy-coney-barrett-could-mean-for-future-of-the-supreme-court-11601155192?mod=hp_lead_pos1&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">textualist</a>,” meaning she focuses on the original text of the Constitution rather than trying to determine lawmakers' intent.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">It’s more clear where Barrett stands on social issues like abortion than on business cases. But if confirmed, she’d face plenty of private sector battles.  </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Big Tech:</strong></span><span> </span><span><a href="https://www.protocol.com/supreme-court-nominee-future-of-tech?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Section 230</a></span><span>, a provision granting tech platforms legal immunity from what users post (and a Trump administration target), will likely make its way to the Supreme Court in the coming years. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">The power of corporations: </strong></span><span>An upcoming case looks at fatal car accidents involving malfunctioning Ford cars. Barrett won’t be involved in this case, but if the court </span><span><a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2020/09/24/finance-202-big-business-eyes-more-wins-with-padded-conservative-majority-supreme-court/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">sides with Ford</a></span><span> in limiting the circumstances under which corporations can be sued, it could kick off an era of decisions favorable to big business.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Still...“A conservative philosophy doesn’t necessarily mean a pro-business outcome,” William Jay, another former Scalia clerk, <a href="https://www.barrons.com/articles/how-a-more-conservative-supreme-court-could-redefine-free-enterprise-51601070282?mod=article_signInButton?mod=article_signInButton&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">told Barron’s</a>.</p>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
APPAREL
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/09/27/allbirds-raises-100-million-17-billion-valuation?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
What's Allbirds Up To?
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Allbirds store" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yNTMwL2FsbGJpcmRzX3N0b3JlLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>David M. Benett/Dave Benett/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Just raising a fresh <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/sustainable-footwear-maker-allbirds-lands-100-million-in-funding-11601208000?mod=pls_whats_news_us_business_f&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">$100 million round</a>, according to the WSJ. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The company is now valued at $1.7 billion. But before you say “by golly that’s impressive,” remember that Allbirds was valued at $1.4 billion two years ago. That’s not the valuation growth rate you come to expect from Silicon Valley's star-studded unicorns.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The backstory: </strong>Allbirds <a href="https://www.inc.com/cameron-albert-deitch/allbirds-2018-company-of-the-year-nominee.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">launched</a> in 2016 as a direct-to-consumer footwear brand committed to sustainably made products. Its $95 Wool Runner sneaker quickly became a staple of the modern tech worker’s wardrobe, and it earned $100 million in revenue in its first two years. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But once you have a hit, figuring out what to do next is the tricky part—just ask Billy Ray Cyrus. To maintain its mojo, Allbirds has expanded into socks, underwear, and other shoe styles (including a running sneaker), and last week launched a <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/retail/stories/2020/09/23/allbirds-launched-proprietary-shopping-app?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">standalone shopping app</a>. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead…</strong>despite the pandemic, Allbirds plans to expand its physical store footprint from 21 locations currently, per the WSJ. It’s one of many digitally native brands to see promise in a blend of online and brick-and-mortar channels.</p>

<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
TRAVEL
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/09/27/china-hits-road-golden-week?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
China Hits the Road
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Tourists take a selfie at the the Yellow Crane Tower in Wuhan, China's c..." style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yNTMxL2NoaW5hLWhlYWx0aC13dWhhbi5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Hector Retamal/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In the world of travel, China’s “Golden Week” holiday is like Labor Day, Memorial Day, and the Wednesday before Thanksgiving rolled into one. Beginning Oct. 1, more than 600 million trips are <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/china-coronavirus-holiday-travel-golden-week/2020/09/25/59d512a2-fe31-11ea-b0e4-350e4e60cc91_story.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">expected</a> as Chinese people set their OOO messages and hit the road.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Of course, things will be different this year—not <em>all</em> worse, though.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Domestic flight trips are projected to </span><span><a href="https://www.scmp.com/business/china-business/article/3102133/golden-week-record-number-chinese-travellers-planning?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">increase 10%</a></span><span> because of curbs on international travel.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Bookings for luxury hotels, especially, are skyrocketing. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>And in Wuhan, the city where the coronavirus originated, the Yellow Crane Tower is the most sought-after attraction in the entire country during Golden Week. Number two? Shanghai Disneyland. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Still, the pandemic is stunting overall travel; those 600 million trips are <a href="https://www.scmp.com/news/china/society/article/3103150/ready-set-holiday-chinas-golden-week-travellers-head-wide-open?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">down</a> from 782 million last year. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>China’s largely kept the coronavirus under control since the initial outbreak. It detected its first local asymptomatic cases in more than a month last week.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
FROM THE CREW
</h3>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><em>Every Monday, we curate a handful of balanced resources about a hot-button business issue and encourage you to discuss with friends, family, or coworkers. </em></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">This week’s topic:</strong> Should workers be allowed to wear Black Lives Matter (BLM) gear at work? </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The backdrop: </strong>This summer, Wawa and Starbucks revised their policies to allow employees to wear BLM apparel. But other companies, including Costco, Whataburger, and Amazon-owned Whole Foods, have allegedly retaliated against employees who wore BLM clothing or accessories. Last Thursday, Facebook <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/24/facebook-wont-let-employees-use-political-profile-photos-internally.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">banned employees</a> from displaying any messages in their profile pictures promoting a political or social cause. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>What options do employers have? (</span><span><a href="https://hrdailyadvisor.blr.com/2020/09/10/some-employers-struggling-with-blm-apparel-at-work/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">HR Daily Advisor</a></span><span>)</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Is it even legal? (</span><span><a href="https://www.theemployerhandbook.com/is-it-legal-to-forbid-employees-from-wearing-black-lives-matter-mask-or-insignia-at-work/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">FisherBroyles</a></span><span>)</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Allowing employees to wear attire celebrating one movement (such as LGBTQ rights) but not BLM could be grounds for discrimination. (</span><span><a href="https://www.detroitnews.com/story/business/2020/07/07/workplace-masks-black-lives-matter/112096526/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">The Detroit News</a></span><span>)</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>The federal government ruled that its employees are allowed to wear BLM apparel without violating the Hatch Act. (</span><span><a href="https://www.govexec.com/management/2020/07/federal-employees-may-wear-or-display-black-lives-matter-paraphernalia-work/166956/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Government Executive</a></span><span>)</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>First Amendment protections are fuzzier when it comes to private employers. (</span><span><a href="https://news.bloomberglaw.com/daily-labor-report/free-speech-rights-fuzzy-for-blm-shirt-confederate-flag-at-work?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Bloomberg Law</a></span><span>)</span>
</li>
</ul>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</th>
</tr>

Images\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eLast night, the New York Times released a \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/09/27/us/donald-trump-taxes.html?referringSource=articleShare\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edetailed rundown\u003c/a\u003e of President Trump’s financial dealings based on tax return data spanning more than two decades. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eGo ahead and slap the “bombshell” label on this investigation, because the president's tax returns are some of the most sought-after documents in the world. Trump, who ran a sprawling business operation before running for president, broke precedent by becoming the first president since the 1970s to keep his tax returns under wraps. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eKey takeaways\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eFor a billionaire, Trump paid very little income tax. \u003c/strong\u003eIn 10 of 15 years leading up to his 2016 election, Trump paid $0 of federal income tax “largely because he reported losing much more money than he made,\" the NYT writes. In 2016 and 2017, he paid $750 each year. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eHe made a lot of money from saying “You’re fired.” \u003c/strong\u003eTrump’s TV show \u003cem\u003eThe Apprentice \u003c/em\u003ebrought in \u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/nyt-trump-paid-750-in-federal-income-taxes-in-2016-and-2017-b15150cd-1a05-4e6e-8f0d-7dfd2c2fa1ac.html?utm_source=twitter\u0026utm_medium=social\u0026utm_campaign=organic\u0026utm_content=1100\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e$427.4 million\u003c/a\u003e including licensing and endorsement deals associated with his personal brand. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe NYT also found that he took tax deductions on $70,000 he spent on hairstyling for his television appearances. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eGolf is a tough business for Trump.\u003c/strong\u003e The report found that many of the president’s signature properties, including his various golf courses and hotels, have been losing millions of dollars every year, resulting in lower taxes. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eA bill looms\u003c/strong\u003e. More than $300 million in loans that Trump is personally responsible for will come due in the next four years, per the NYT. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eWhat Trump is saying\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eTrump’s camp is beating the “fake news” drum once again. “Most, if not all, of the facts appear to be inaccurate,” a Trump Organization lawyer told the NYT, going on to say in a statement that President Trump has paid “millions in personal taxes since announcing his candidacy in 2015.”\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eIn a press conference last night, Trump echoed his lawyer, saying that an IRS audit of his taxes is currently underway and will paint a more accurate picture. “It’ll all be revealed,” \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/sep/27/new-york-times-publishes-donald-trumps-tax-returns-election?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehe said\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003eyou can bet this report will be brought up in the \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2020/09/27/politics/biden-trump-no-handshake-first-presidential-debate/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efirst debate\u003c/a\u003e between President Trump and Joe Biden tomorrow night. The NYT also promised to release additional investigations related to these tax documents in the coming weeks.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" via Getty Images\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOn Saturday, President Trump \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2020/09/27/politics/amy-coney-barrett-supreme-court-trump-election-2020/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003enominated\u003c/a\u003e Judge Amy Coney Barrett, a conservative favorite, to occupy the Supreme Court seat vacated when Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg died over a week ago. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eA longtime Notre Dame law professor and a clerk to the late Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia in the 1990s, Barrett is considered a “\u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/what-trump-pick-amy-coney-barrett-could-mean-for-future-of-the-supreme-court-11601155192?mod=hp_lead_pos1\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etextualist\u003c/a\u003e,” meaning she focuses on the original text of the Constitution rather than trying to determine lawmakers' intent.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIt’s more clear where Barrett stands on social issues like abortion than on business cases. But if confirmed, she’d face plenty of private sector battles.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig Tech:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.protocol.com/supreme-court-nominee-future-of-tech?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eSection 230\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e, a provision granting tech platforms legal immunity from what users post (and a Trump administration target), will likely make its way to the Supreme Court in the coming years. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe power of corporations: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAn upcoming case looks at fatal car accidents involving malfunctioning Ford cars. Barrett won’t be involved in this case, but if the court \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2020/09/24/finance-202-big-business-eyes-more-wins-with-padded-conservative-majority-supreme-court/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eDavid M. Benett/Dave Benett/Getty Images\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eJust raising a fresh \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/sustainable-footwear-maker-allbirds-lands-100-million-in-funding-11601208000?mod=pls_whats_news_us_business_f\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e$100 million round\u003c/a\u003e, according to the WSJ. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe company is now valued at $1.7 billion. But before you say “by golly that’s impressive,” remember that Allbirds was valued at $1.4 billion two years ago. That’s not the valuation growth rate you come to expect from Silicon Valley's star-studded unicorns.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe backstory: \u003c/strong\u003eAllbirds \u003ca href=\"https://www.inc.com/cameron-albert-deitch/allbirds-2018-company-of-the-year-nominee.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003elaunched\u003c/a\u003e in 2016 as a direct-to-consumer footwear brand committed to sustainably made products. Its $95 Wool Runner sneaker quickly became a staple of the modern tech worker’s wardrobe, and it earned $100 million in revenue in its first two years. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut once you have a hit, figuring out what to do next is the tricky part—just ask Billy Ray Cyrus. To maintain its mojo, Allbirds has expanded into socks, underwear, and other shoe styles (including a running sneaker), and last week launched a \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/retail/stories/2020/09/23/allbirds-launched-proprietary-shopping-app?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003estandalone shopping app\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead…\u003c/strong\u003edespite the pandemic, Allbirds plans to expand its physical store footprint from 21 locations currently, per the WSJ. collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn the world of travel, China’s “Golden Week” holiday is like Labor Day, Memorial Day, and the Wednesday before Thanksgiving rolled into one. Beginning Oct. 1, more than 600 million trips are \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/china-coronavirus-holiday-travel-golden-week/2020/09/25/59d512a2-fe31-11ea-b0e4-350e4e60cc91_story.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eexpected\u003c/a\u003e as Chinese people set their OOO messages and hit the road.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOf course, things will be different this year—not \u003cem\u003eall\u003c/em\u003e worse, though.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eDomestic flight trips are projected to \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.scmp.com/business/china-business/article/3102133/golden-week-record-number-chinese-travellers-planning?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eincrease 10%\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e because of curbs on international travel.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eBookings for luxury hotels, especially, are skyrocketing. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAnd in Wuhan, the city where the coronavirus originated, the Yellow Crane Tower is the most sought-after attraction in the entire country during Golden Week. Number two? Shanghai Disneyland. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eStill, the pandemic is stunting overall travel; those 600 million trips are \u003ca href=\"https://www.scmp.com/news/china/society/article/3103150/ready-set-holiday-chinas-golden-week-travellers-head-wide-open?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edown\u003c/a\u003e from 782 million last year. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eChina’s largely kept the coronavirus under control since the initial outbreak. style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eEvery Monday, we curate a handful of balanced resources about a hot-button business issue and encourage you to discuss with friends, family, or coworkers. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThis week’s topic:\u003c/strong\u003e Should workers be allowed to wear Black Lives Matter (BLM) gear at work? \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe backdrop: \u003c/strong\u003eThis summer, Wawa and Starbucks revised their policies to allow employees to wear BLM apparel. But other companies, including Costco, Whataburger, and Amazon-owned Whole Foods, have allegedly retaliated against employees who wore BLM clothing or accessories. Last Thursday, Facebook \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/24/facebook-wont-let-employees-use-political-profile-photos-internally.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebanned employees\u003c/a\u003e from displaying any messages in their profile pictures promoting a political or social cause. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eWhat options do employers have? (\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://hrdailyadvisor.blr.com/2020/09/10/some-employers-struggling-with-blm-apparel-at-work/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eHR Daily Advisor\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e)\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eIs it even legal? (\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.theemployerhandbook.com/is-it-legal-to-forbid-employees-from-wearing-black-lives-matter-mask-or-insignia-at-work/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eFisherBroyles\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e)\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eAllowing employees to wear attire celebrating one movement (such as LGBTQ rights) but not BLM could be grounds for discrimination. (\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.detroitnews.com/story/business/2020/07/07/workplace-masks-black-lives-matter/112096526/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eThe Detroit News\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e)\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eThe federal government ruled that its employees are allowed to wear BLM apparel without violating the Hatch Act. (\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.govexec.com/management/2020/07/federal-employees-may-wear-or-display-black-lives-matter-paraphernalia-work/166956/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eGovernment Executive\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e)\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eFirst Amendment protections are fuzzier when it comes to private employers. (\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://news.bloomberglaw.com/daily-labor-report/free-speech-rights-fuzzy-for-blm-shirt-confederate-flag-at-work?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eBloomberg Law\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e)\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/th\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c!--[if
